IV. Administrative Structure:
Without regard to who is to be which organization, it is obviously essential
that we have, as listed above:
1) A strong professional organization
2) A Network exchange mechanism (both for TV and radio)
3) A facility for collecting materials (which Wilbur Schramm compares to a
New York office of the AP)
k) Legislative representation
5) A source of aid, comfort, and advice, which is in essence the spirit of
the NAEB.
Certainly it will be essential to have the first two organizations mentioned
above. "The New York office of the AP," as a source of materials might well be
included in our Washington office. The latter, if it is to take over from the
JCET its most essential functions and also provide liasion with the ACE, naces®
sazy lobby activities, and tape and film studios, should probably be located in
a large building with the AP and perhaps a Center representative.
Our present management and legal council could be somewhat expanded, as we
thus move into the Washington picture. It is believed that we would no longer
need an engineering consultant or a legal consultant aside from those provided
by the NAEB as the professional society Involved. The combination resulting in
Washington would then preserve the functions of the NAEB, the ETEC and the JCET.
Most of the functions of the NCGET can now be considered as virtually completed.
(Some areas feel that their influence has done great harm in ary case).
Replacing the JCET, but as a new committee of the NAEB, might be something
like a JEAC: Joint Educational Advisory Council. This might include the present
JCET Board, plus representative of Teachers Colleges, School Board Associations,
Classroom Teachers Associations, the National PTA, the Junior League, the Federa¬
tion of Women3 s Clubs, the AAUW, the League of Women Voters, the NUEA (National
University Extension Association), Associations of Principals, the AEA, etc.
These representatives might be on a rotating basis (with the MENC, for ex¬
ample, in an active status this year, but replaced next year by another organi¬
zation) . An executive committee of the above council would meet with the NAEB
Board once a year.
The additional functions visualized for the Washington office, were essen¬
tially legal, lobby, liasion, and reporting.
